Judeau

Scientists say that gravity compared to electromagnetic pulses is 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 times weaker as far as attraction goes. We have magnets that can lift objects off the ground that are nowhere near the size of the earth. Even with the mass of the earth, the gravity is easily defeated by tiny magnets. The explanation I heard telling why the vast difference related to String Theory. It said that there were many universes. In our universe, electromagnetic force is very strong but can only affect our universe. Gravity on the other hand traverses many universes. Imagine our universe as a sheet of paper. EM force can only affect what is drawn on that piece of paper. Now imagine a stack of papers as many universes. Gravity originating from our universe can affect the entire stack of papers making it affect more dimensions. This reduces gravity's overall effect on our universe but it is theorized to be equally as strong as EM, just disbursed differently. Does anyone have any other explanations for why gravity is such a weak force? Or can someone explain to me why gravity can transcend our universe but not EM? I only know the minor basics of this theory and I would be interested to learn more about it if anyone knows.
Jo Bennett

I'm not well up on it, it was only touched on in my 4th year particle physics lectures, but suffice to say calling it a theory at present is a bit pushing it, it's a hypothesis, I don't think there is much mroe detail. It's one of the products of late night discussions between very stoned post-docs as far as I can tell.
electrolyte

Does anyone have any other explanations for why gravity is such a weak force?

 What you're really asking is, "Why is the gravitational constant so small relative to other constants?"
 
 Here's something one of my physics professors pointed out: There are positive and negative charges. There are opposite magnetic poles (i.e. no magnetic monopoles). These therefore can get "cancelled."
 There is no opposite of gravity. It cannot get "cancelled." If it were as strong as these other constants, gravity's effect would dwarf the effects of others.
 
 But of course, here's my take:
 Why is the charge of an electron −1.602 × 10^−19 C? Why is the permittivity of free space 8.85 × 10^−12 F/m? Why is the speed of light in a vacuum 2.998 × 10^8 m/s?
zachvac

Well if gravity were as strong or stronger than magnets, we would all be flying at each other. If you were in a crowded room the forces of gravity would have you flying every which way (which would cause other people to fly every which way, etc.) I don't know if there's really an answer to why though, may as well ask why we exist. We can answer many questions about the universe and life itself, but why is not one of them.

 You say this as if tweaking this single constant will change only the things we immediately associate with large-scale gravitational effects, and as if said space junk and moons (and Earth and humans) would actually exist as we know them.
 The universe works as it is. If the universe were different, it would either:
 1) not work, in which case we wouldn't be around to ask any questions, or
 2) work, in which case we'd be asking the very same question and wondering how "weird" it is that things are however they are...

There is no reason to question why constant x is the way it is, lest we ask the same of constants y, z, etc. I thought I included in my earlier post (but obviously didn't), "The universe works as it is." Science doesn't answer such "why" questions.

 
 Actually that might not be true. There's a hypothesis doing the rounds that our universe - or rather the laws that govern its behaviour - evolved.
 
 I won't be able to do it justice, but it goes something like this: new universes are born within black holes. Too much gravity and you just get one big black hole: one 'offspring'. Too little and you get no black holes; a 'sterile' universe. Vary the governing constants (or, according to string theory, the geometry of the universe) a bit, and matter starts to 'clump'. Our universe is really good at making black holes, and also happens to be capable of giving rise to us. According to the hypothesis, it is one offspring of a very similar universe - one of many, in fact. Variation and natural selection on a universal scale results in squillions of universes capable of supporting life as we know it, simply because they're also good at making black holes.
 
 Cool, huh?
